description.text:
oversized model
has holes to be wired to a wire-fence
ABS prints can be fused together with a few drops of acetone (nail polish remover)
designed 2 versions to store my television remotes. both the versions will hold 3 remotes and is probably best to glue or tape them onto the table or where you want to place them.

Here is a spherical Christmas ornament decorated with the recursive snowflake described in thing:35439.  An opening in the base allows the insertion of a light.
The snowflake is not planar but has been "bent" to fit the surface of a sphere.  The walls of the ornament are 1.5 mm thick and the snowflake is inscribed in the surface to a depth of one mm. A light of the right frequency placed inside the ornament passes through the 0.5 mm thick wall and outlines the snowflake.
The image shown at the upper left is of a blue ABS ornament placed on a LED coaster.  The light is from a blue LED.  Similar results occur if a green LED is used.  However the blue ABS ornament (Helsinki Sky from Makerbot) does not pass light  from red or yellow LED's.
Red, yellow, green or blue LED's can be used with a natural ABS ornament.
A red ABS ornament is illuminated by a red LED but does not work well with blue or green LEDs.
I printed the ornaments on a Replicator using 1 shell and 5% infill.  The ornaments can be printed directly on the build surface.  They weight about 16 grams and are 70 mm in diameter.

Prevents your u-lock from being stolen while you are riding
Update: checkout the new version, providing cable shafts
This is a customizable version of this lockholder
A mount for u-locks on bikes. Provides a lot of settings to fit on your bike and lock.

What you need
  • A bike and a u-lock (well, that's obvious)
  • A 3D-Printer (probably you wouldn't be here otherwise)
  • 8 equal screws (should be a bit longer than twice the thickness of your print - I would recommend 1 - 2 cm)
  • 8 equal nuts fitting on your screws
    How to build it
    1. Measuring
      • Measure the diameter of your bike's top tube (or another round tube where you want to mount the lock
      • Measure the diameter of your u-lock. As you will later slide the u-lock through the holder, measure the thickest area of the u-part of the lock.
      • Measure the diameter of your nuts (if you were laughing now, please grow up). Measure the flat size (look here: Wikipedia: Nut, measure A/F)
      • Measure the diameter of your screw's thread
    2. Start the Customizer and edit the settings
    3. Print it (you are on your own with this step)
    4. To mount the printed parts, use the screws and nuts. The offset between the two lockholders can be determined easiest when you fix one lockholder on your bike and slide the lock through it.

title: Wersybot - a derivate of The Printrbot

description.text:
Brook Drumm created the wonderful original which is far more rigid and can print much better then most of you would think. It is a great design with small overall dimension but for all that with a big print area. This is the reason that there are a lot of derivates. Thank you very much Brook for that genius idea.
My intention was to be as close as possible to the original parts but with a lot improvements.
Here is one of my first prints: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lmT9ujijztQ

comments.text: Where did you get the Firmware for your RAMPS board?
comments.author: TheProfessor

comments.text:
Hi,
I would be very glad if you build my Wersybot.
It can be a surprisingly precision printer. It depends only on how accurate you align the rods. They must be absolutely right angled in all directions, which is very easy to control.
And of course the parts should be printed well, mainly the base parts. They are bigger as the originals and therefore a bit more difficult to print without warping.
The smaller you build the printer, the more stable it is.
My printer has a build volume of x =164 mm, y =144 mm, z =165 mm. This size enable to use a PCB heat bed MK2 if needed.
I printed with it all parts of the things you can see on Thingiverse.
And yes, I use the Marlin software. You can download it on GitHub: https://github.com/ErikZalm/Marlin/tree/Marlin_v1https://github.com/ErikZalm/Ma...
comments.author: TheProfessor

comments.text: Personally, I see no reason to make a derivative of the printrbot with a different name. It is a printrbot with some changes, but I don't think it is enough to change the name.
comments.author: gwc

comments.text:
Looking at it from this perspective, you are correct; although I have modified and upgraded every part of the original Printrbot.
I just wanted to make shure that there can be no mistaking my Printrbot from the original Printrbot.

comments.text: I mean I described all my thoughts very detailed. Did you read all? I'm sorry if you can't see any improvements. Maybe they are not very essential. Anyhow, the print quality is much better as I ever expected :-)Â
comments.author: rrhb

comments.text: apologies - not meant to imply that you weren't getting great results, in fact, the opposite. There were a few places where I wasn't clear whether the change was a result of testing against the original design, trying to use parts you might have had on hand, ensuring 100% metric, experience in building other bots, etc. Â Nothing substantial and indeed you documented your thoughts better than most. For instance, the switch to Â z-coupler and the reference to the single M4 in the x-end-idler or the x-end motor add'l threaded hole, or separating out the y endstop from the clamp - was this because the original design had issues for you?
comments.author: wersy

comments.text:
Thank you for your reply. I am glad if anybody is asking for details.
No, I had no experience with 3D printing at all as I started to design. But I watched very intensive all assembly videos of abdrumm several times. Doing so I was sure what I would like to change.
Before this I studied mostly the MendelMax and Mendel90 - theoretically ;-) The only experience I have is with my own Printer now :-)
I prefer nophead's z-coupling because of the plastic hose between the motor shaft and the coupling. I think it gives a good grip makes the connection a bit elastically and allows angular movement if the rod is not straight.
The x-end-idler has no place for a second fixing screw. It would be only possible from the other side. But then the x-ends must be thicker but I want to keep the x-ends slim.
" the x-end motor add'l threaded hole" Which hole exactly you mean?
Much later I found this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17986http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
It is only a question of time till one comes to similar thoughts.

title: Thing-o-Matic 40 mm Fan Guard (No hardware required)

description.text:
I still keep sticking my alan wrench into the fan blades by accident. After replacing the fan for a 4th time I decided it was time to make a grill guard. I based this on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:188358 - I added a couple split pegs to push this into the top un-utilized holes of the fan. This simply pushes on. I added a light-weight piece of kapton tape along the bottom to keep it from vibrating while running (optional).
Note when I printed this (because it's only 3 layers thick the center pulled out. I'm not too concerned about the center so I mounted it anyhow.

Print (0.35mm layer height)
Push the split pins into the top two holes of the fan
Profit!

description.text:
Small, Printable Quadro Copter
  • Cabling is still a bit alpha version on the pictures :)

Partlist:
  • 8 x KA 25 x 16 WN Screws to attach the Arm
  • 4 - 8 x KA 22 x 6 WN Screws to attach the Feet to the arms
  • 4 x Motors, i used Turnigy Aerodrive SK3 2822-1275 Brushless Outrunner with Short Shaft
  • 4 x ESC, i used Hobbyking SS Series 18-20A ESC, flashed with SimonK firmware, but it's probably easier to buy Afro ESC's with the Firmware already installed.
  • 4 x Props, i used 7x3.8 Turnigy Slow Fly Electric, 2 colors, each one counter rotating.
  • 1 x Hobbyking KK2.1.5 Multi-rotor LCD Flight Control Board
  • 1 x R/C Receiver
  • a bit of felt to put between the arm and the cross of the motors
  • And of Course a Battery, some Cables, Soldering tools

author: alberpao

title: Craft Cutter holder for QuickFit Carriage

description.text: With this item, you can use the quickfit carriage to hold a craft cutter blade. These blades are very thin rotating blades that can cut paper, light duty plastics, vinyl, etc.

You'll need:
  • A replacement craft cutting blade.
  • A replacement cutting mat with a tacky surface -or- the separate tacky surface and mat.
  • A way to generate an outline GCODE file (Inkscape & the Unicorn Plugin)
  • An installed QuickFit carriage (although this one could be modified to mount directly - let me know if there's demand for that I can make that change).
    • Don't attempt until your printer is well dialed in. The tolerance for cutting through a single sheet of paper (and nothing else) is very tight.
  • Print this item
  • Insert craft cutter blade, tighten in with bolt and nut
  • Place paper on top of tacky cutting mat, and then on top of printer bed.
  • Clamp everything down with clips.
  • Adjust z-height so craft blade penetrates the paper but no deeper.
  • Generate an outline GCODE file. There are a variety of ways: A common favorite is the Inkscape Unicorn PlugIn, but it's also possible to generate it from an SCAD!
  • Print!
    • This is a work in progress because there are two ways to insert the craft cutter blade. One tends to squeeze the cutter house and deforms it a bit, making it not as a stable, but the other mounting direction doesn't quite clear the rather deep quick x-carriage. Maybe one of you will have some thoughts?

comments.text: Do you have a link to which specific cutter this is made for?

author: rrhb

description.text: I have given several presentations about my DIY Prusa Mendel 3D-printer and wanted to give the visitors a small 3D printed gadget. For that, I made the space invaders (thing:18395) 50% smaller, so I could print a lot of them in a relative short amount of time. I changed the hole so it fits a tiny cylindrical 4 by 2 mm magnet.

Buy cylindrical magnets. 4 mm diameter, 2 mm height.
Print the space invaders and insert the magnet.
Although the I have to press fit the magnets, I also apply a small drop of glue on each magnet.
When the magnet does not fit the space invader printed on your printer try to enlarge or shrink it a few percent using a program like netfabb basic.

description.text: I have a Makerbot Mini, and OK, the small spools.... and plenty of 2Kg PLA options on large ones.  So here is my simple/stupid adapter that lets you use a Mini on any spool.

Print out the adapter with the slot facing up for no need for supports. Mine was on the Mini at 25% infill. The STL file is in inches. You'll need 31.75 cm of 3.8mm Teflon tubing (.150 inch). I used two thin 1/2" velour pads from a Dollar Store pack on one side of the slot. This is enough to provide a nice friction to keep the adapter in place. The spool is set behind the Mini on any number of options for spool holders, like this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:169080 My setup uses two mini T-slot rails and some M8 rod and bearings.

description.text:
Here are two ornaments, one based on a 432 electron solution to the Thomson problem; the second on a 522 electron solution. See
http://www-wales.ch.cam.ac.uk/~wales/CCD/Thomson/table.html
The coordinates of the electrons were used to create polyhedron duals. Both duals have 24 pentagonal faces and 12 heptagonal faces with the remainder of the faces being hexagonal ones. The heptagonal faces each share edges with 2 pentagonal ones. A heptagonal face, surrounded by 5 hexagonal and 2 pentagonal faces, is clearly shown in the left hand image above. This pattern occurs in solutions to the Thompson problem presented at the above web site and containing more than 400 electrons.
On my Replicator I printed the ornaments using external support.

author: SeanSu

title: Simple Fruit Picker for small fruit like cherry

description.text:
A simple fruit picker for small fruit like cherry. Basically a similiar design like the one my grandpa always has used for picking apples (but that was in the last century and wasn't 3d printed)
The outline is half circle so the handle fits on the print bed. Just add a bag (I used gauze from insect protection for window) and a handle (I used a telescopic rod for wall painting). The socket is a press fit for the rod used, adjust the scad params accordingly.

The stls supplied are for 120mm diameter with 7 cutouts and 140mm diameter with 9 cutouts. These fit on my print bed and are suitable for cherry. If you need different, adjust params P20 - P22 accordingly.
The handle socket is 30mm long, slightly conical with 21mm inner and 23mm outer diameters and tight fits a 3m telescopic rod normally used for wall painting. If you need another socket, adjust params P31 - P33 in the scad file accordingly.
The attachment bores are for M3 screws.
For the bag I used surplus gauze I had available. The bag is fixated using M3 screws and closed using cable ties. Or use some textile material, e.g. an old T-shirt just as well.
I printed with 2 perimeters and 20% infill and the tool is strong enough.

comments.text:
Well, it worked for me. But then we are only using the cherries for ourselves and have a tall tree where professional picking according to the proper ISO regulated cherry picking procedure is not required...
PS.
OK, all of you, let me tell you my secret trick for preventing the cherries from rotting. It is an old family secret and I am not sure if I am entitled to share it here. But anyways. Here it comes: The secret trick for preventing the cherries from rotting is: Eat them! Eat them right away! Well, not really right away. Wash them first. But right after washing: Eat them. I mean it. Or give them to someone else and make sure they eat them right away. After all, we don't want the cherries to rot. And if you are really really quick, they will not rot. I promise. It always works for me. You might also try making a fruit jam or a cake or whatever. But you really have to be quick about it. In fact, better make sure the oven for the cake is preheated before you start picking the cherries. And no facebook, no whats app, no thingiverse in between. No 3D printing either! The cherries are top priority here!

Sustain Pedal for an electronic piano The pedal-jack must be connected to the outlet of the piano marked with "Sustain Pedal" and not to "Phones" or "Line out". YouTube:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bgyiMLbHb24

3D printing:
1 - Sustain Pedal
1 - SustainBase
1- Caps You need one of the following
  • 2 screws 5 mm in diameter, about 20 mm long
  • Tube 5 mm in diameter 40 mm in length
    • You need You also need
  • 1 Jack plug
  • some wire 1-2 meter
  • Some wire
  • two springs
    • It is possible that the hole must be drilled up if screws or pipe is too big. Function
    The pedal functions by connecting the wires together when the pedal is depressed. The wire consists of two conductors. One will be connected to the spring and the other connected to the metal wires at the end of the pedal. This must adjust so that there is contact between the leaders when the pedal is pressed and the contact is broken when the pedal is released.

title: Simple Filament Spool Stand V3: easy-print remix

description.text:
I changed the joint between stand and bar to have no overhangs less than 45° and made sure it prints nicely with a brim. For this I remodeled the whole thing in FreeCAD 0.13; file attached.
Like the original this model is scalable. The provided STL prints to a height of 105mm. On the photos you see a print that was scaled by 1.7 in height and width, but not thickness. That's the largest my printer can handle and I still found the 8mm thickness of the stand sufficient. Just make sure to scale the bar accordingly.
The bars are provided in 5 sizes (given dimensions are end-to-end).

Recommended layer height: 0.3mm.
4-6mm brim highly recommended.
1mm perimeter and 20% - 30% honeycomb infill work for me.

The original Tantillus does not have Home sensor for X and Y, http://www.tantillus.org.
For me this is very important because my idea of a 3D printer is just "click and print". So I made this addon for the acrilic version (which I bought from http://www.indiegogo.com/tantillus) which requires no modification to the original parts.

These parts are easy to print.
Insert the nut and the M3 screw, fix the micro-switch with the Self Tapping screws and conect to the driver board. The Y Home Sensor is fixed on the top of the structure on the left side, close to the top-right-front corner.
The X sensor is fixed on the front panel, through the front window, close to the top-left-front corner. For calibration, it is recomended to first move the cariage manualy to the extreme position and then adjust the sensor (you can hear it click). This will prevent that it breaks in case of an excessive cariage movement. BOM vitamins needed:
1) 2x micro-switch 20mm like this one: http://br.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Honeywell/ZV10B70A01/?qs=sGAEpiMZZMtFyPk3yBMYYI0nvXV6ddkcmIv%2fkeci2vU%3d
2) 4x self-tapping screw 2.2x9.5mm like this one: http://www.conrad-uk.com/ce/en/product/228737/TOOLCRAFT-DIN-7971-flat-top-sheet-metal-screws-with-slot-Galvanised-steel-22-mm-20-Units/2304030&ref=list
3) 2x screw M3x4
4) 2x nut M3

My filament often snags and gives me headaches and breaks things. This is a faiisafe

Mounts a microswitch behind the Metric Prusa Clip on Filament Guide thing:18889. Clamp an M8 bolt to the Z-rod top using a bar clamp.
Aim the bolt at the back of the filament guide, and mount this on the bolt end.
Bolt a microswitch onto it and wire it to the killswitch input (I have an LCD thing so I hijacked pin 63 on aux2 on ramps). When the filament snags it bends the guide back, and just before it snaps the printer stops. More peace of mind for unattended printing.

Pretty much identical to the one here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35402
except rectangular, with legs and a bent vacuum connection..
I also added more holes and grid lines to allow for more detailed molding

Print with at least 2 layers and an infill of about 20% or more.
should print with out support. glue the stand and the gasket and the base together. (Use hot glue or something to seal any gaps it needs to be air tight)
place a rubber band around the poles of the stand. to allow for a better seal between the mounts and the stand when forming. I used Magnets in the Plastic mounts to hold them together.. but you can use screws and bolts or you can hinge them together if you want. use the Platstic template to draw the shape on the bottom of a plastic plate then cut that shape out of the plates..
these will be the plastic sheets you use with this machine. you will need a pretty good vacuum to connect this too, I used my small house vac but it needed an adapter to fit the shop vac sized hole. so I included that too. (you may need to alter it to match your vacuum) Also you will need a heat gun. tempreture is everything.. if the plastic sheets don't get hot enough.. the final mold will not have enought detail. To use Vacuum Former:
Turn on your vacuum,
Place the thing you want to make a mold of on the stand..
Then heat your plastic in the mounts.
when the plastic gets hot enough, press the mounts down on to the base and the vacuum will do the rest.

This is a remix from the "space navigator for notebooks" handrest, it fits the desktop version.
I made my inlay out of silicone, so it is even more comfortable to use. But you can also print it out of Plastic.
The bottom part is available as one part or a version to glue two halves together, if the printer is too small to print the whole thing. (like mine)

Print the bottom half. (the one or the two part solution)
If you want the inlay out of plastic, just print it.
If you want the inlay out of silicone (like mine) print the mould, sand it smooth, rub some liquid soap on it (helps to get the silicone out of the mould) squeeze the silicone into the mould, make sure the top part is flat.
wait until the silicone is cured and unmold it.
Done!

title: Chamfered Edge Soma UnPlated (now with a BOX)

description.text:
This is AdanA's chamfered Edge Soma Cube, but broken apart by individual pieces.
When I attempted to print AdanA's Soma cube, my filament stopped flowing at the 1 1/2 cube height, wrecking three of the pieces.
Rather than print them all out again, I separated out the individual pieces.
If anyone else needs to print just one replacement, this will save a bit of PLA/ABS.
So that I would be less likely to lose the pieces, and having just recently attained the coveted rank of junior-newbie-beginner in openSCAD, I created a box to hold the pieces.
Please note that my picture shows my first attempt which turned out to be 2 mm too high.  I've fixed this, but didn't bother to print the correction for myself.

title: Simple mendelmax psu mount for common 12v 30a PSUs

description.text:
I wanted to mount my PSU to the side of my mendelmax, but couldn't find any mounts that suited me. My criteria were:
No need to use expensive t-nuts you insert from the side of the extrusion, and no disassembly.
Unobtrusive and cheap (in terms of plastic.)

Print. Hold in place, bolt through the hole to the PSU with a 30mm M4 bolt, through a washer.
I was surprised at how well just two of these hold the psu, if you want to you can slightly wobble the top, but it's certainly good enough for me.

description.text: A printable harness to prevent your cables from falling into the abyss when they are not in use. Keep yourself organized and save the frustration. The STL is optimized for USB peripherals the same size as the one that comes with a Makerbot. If you want to fit a different sized cable, scale accordingly. More pictures: http://www.flickr.com/photos/nickstarno/sets/72157624529783381/

• Scale part if needed
  • Print
  • Add a command strip or double sided adhesive strong enough to hold some weight (I used velcro)
  • Attach to desk or flat surface
  • Insert cable (if you made the correct size the cable should be forced in through the top, yet have enough space to move freely once inside)
  • Enjoy!

description.text:
Another PLA cooling mount for 60mm computer cooling fans.
Suitable for Thing-o-matic with MK7.
Adjustable FAN angle.

• Print out the parts. I was able to print them without support, but your success may vary.
    I printed with 0.2 mm layer height and 100% fill, using ABS
  • Put the two parts together.
  • Fasten the fan by inserting it into the slot and using two ~4mm (0.164") screws with nuts to hold it in place.
  • Fasten the long long L-shaped part to holes in the MK7's metal mounting plate.
  • Connect fan wiring.
    I connected the fan wiring with a switch to the power supply

This thing is to put between the eyes (like on the pictures) in the Dive (Commercial Version). The effect that you see the picture from the other eye will so be disabled.
You don't need to glue anything. There is a little gap on the top of the Dive. You only need to put it in there.
It was printed on a Delta Tower with 0.3 Layer high. Please print with 0.3 Layer high, cause i have designed it to be printed on 0.3 Layer high. If you do that, you will get a perfect print which will have a strong hold.

Dieses Teil ist für die Sichtbeschränkung der einzelnen Augen. So wird der Effekt, das man mit einem Auge das Bild des anderen sieht, verhindert.
Es wird nicht benötigt, etwas zu kleben. Es ist ein kleiner Schlitz an der Oberseite der Dive in die das Teil einfach eingesteckt werden muss. Ausgedruckt an einem Delta Tower mit 0.3 Schichtdicke.

title: Wind-Up Engine V1.2 Updated - Fully Printed

description.text: WIP. So far there has not been a successful 3D printed engine but this is the idea: A 3D printed spring's energy is captured and released to a series of gears. The design so far is promising but needs work. Update with upload of V1.2: http://joesmakerbot.blogspot.com/2013/01/fully-3d-printed-engine-update-2.html

Refer to the exploded diagram as you read these steps.
  • Print the spring in ABS with zero fill layers, zero infill, and 4 extra layers. (Not discounting PLA, but I don't know the settings.)
  • Cut the spring at the obtuse angles to make 2 springs. Flip one so that their curves compliment each other (like a flat DNA helix).
  • Print the rest of the pieces with your normal settings.
  • Place the springs inside the case, side by side.
  • Put the drive gear with the straight line of teeth on. Line up the groove beneath the teeth onto the ridge on the case, putting the arm through the hole into the case to cap off the end of the case to compress the springs. (Does anyone have better names for these parts?)
  • Put GearIn1 in the left most hole on the case so that the teeth mesh with the drive's straight teeth.
    7, Glue the pin in the GearFloater. Put it in the next leftmost long hole
  • Put the GearOut1 (with the shorter secondary gear) in the next leftmost hole.
  • Put the two GearOut2s in the last two holes in the case.
  • Put the HolderPlate into the slot in front of the GearIn and bend it to snap into the slot above it making sure the floating gear peg goes into the hole.
  • Take the holderArm and hook one side into the HolderPlate, wrap it around the output gears making sure the pegs hold the gears in place and hook it into the case, pushing the drive gear in slightly and locking it in the case.
  • Glue the key in the hexagonal hole in the GearIn1 gear (not shown in exploded illustration).
    • Wind up the engine to compress the springs. Then let it go. The output gears should not move when winding and when released they should each move at gradating rates. As of this time the actual output speeds and whether they can be slowed down is unknown. Also I suspect that the spring will break frequently so I made easy access to replacing them. Kind of like batteries. If this works it can be used to (briefly?) power an action.

comments.text: i am working of making an energy storage device that can be made by printed parts.. I am leaning more towards a spring coil. there are a couple on thingivers. And what i was thinking is if i wanted to extend the starage capacity.. i can stack them on on top of the other and increase storage by 100 percent with each additional battery coil spring. What i am trying to sort out is a way to regulate the output of the energy.. for example.. i wan tto attach to a smal toy vehicle but instead of having it unwind as quick as it can.. put a kind of braking system in or resister that does not suck up energy.. maybe like a clock pendulum gearing system..?

description.text: A 3D printable Electric Clavichord.

This is a one octave monotonic diatonic 3D printable clavichord. The instrument will use a single electric guitar G string and an electric guitar pickup. It will be very simple to assemble because all of the complex keyboard stuff is printed. I am putting the files up as soon as I create them in order to get feedback and to see if anyone else is interested in this project. What is a clavichord? There are several classes of acoustic keyboard instruments: 1) Piano - the strings are struck with felt covered hammers. When you press a key, the hammer is launched up to strike the string and then drops back to its rest position.
2) Harpsichord - the strings are plucked by plectra. When you strike a key, a jack that contains a springy plectrum (plastic or eagle feather) is launched up to pluck the string and then drops back to it's rest position.
3) Clavichord - the strings are struck with a metal tangent. When you press a key, it acts like a lever with the metal tangent on the other end. The tangent rises up, strikes the string and also frets the string. It stays in contact with the string until you release the key. So the clavichord is a very different instrument to the piano or the harpsichord. Firstly, the pitch of the note is controlled by where the tangent contacts the string. This is what is meant by "fretting" the string. The tangent acts just like the frets on a guitar. Secondly, you have direct physical contact with the string (via the key), whilst the note is sounding, This gives the clavichord "aftertouch". You can change the pitch of the note by pressing harder on the key whilst the note of playing. In fact, it is the acoustic keyboard instrument that has the most degrees of freedom in terms of expression. This might comes a surprise to piano players, but it is true. The great J. S. Bach advised all of his students to learn clavichord in order to develop an exquisite sense of touch. However, it isn't all sweetness and light! the big downside of the clavichord (although some would say this is actually an upside) is that it is very, very, very quiet. A clavichord concert is a strange Zen-like affair where everyone has to sit completely still, and breathe quietly. Even the rustling of clothes can affect your hearing enough to ruin the concert. For a long time now, I have wondered about creating an electronic clavichord. This would have all the touch sensitivity of an acoustic clavichord, but be loud enough to actually hear in a good sized room. This project is my first attempt. Description of the instrument This instrument is a simple 1 octave, diatonic (no sharps or flats) monotonic (only plays one note at a time) electric clavichord. As well as being a proof of concept, it is designed to be a very credible and playable folk instrument. It is very easy to assemble because all of the complex keyboard bits are printed. Progress to date
At the moment, I have the keyframe completed, and the keyboard itself completed minus the tangents. The keyboard/keyframe is a very traditional harpsichord/clavichord mechanism. To Do 1) Tangents.
2) Nut with tuner.
3) Bridge.
4) Mount for electric guitar pickup.
5) Assembly instructions (essentially just glue/screw it down to a baseboard).
6) Upload Sketchup files.

description.text:
This top is a combination of a tippe top and a self-winding top. It is larger than most tippe tops and the self winding feature allows you to spin it very fast. Be careful where you set it down, it can break things. The original design was prototyped in wood.
There is a video of the top in action at: https://vimeo.com/107193608. I hold the top by the ring and give the string a few pulls, almost like a yoyo.

Print the body top down with 100% infill, 2 shells, supports on, and 0.20 mm layer height. It must be printed with 95-100% infill.
Combine the cap, ring and spacer in one print. Lay the ring on its flat face. Position the cap upside down. Position the spacer standing. Use the same settings as the body.
Print the pin separately. Lay it down on it's side so that the grain of the plastic runs along its length. Turn off "supports" when you print the pin.
Use a 1/4" drill bit to ream the hole in the body. Use a slightly larger bit to ream the holes in the ring.
The cap and pin are made separately and glued together with thickened acrylic adhesive. Use paraffin or candle wax as a lubricant between the ring and the pin.
The top's total height when assembled should be approximately 2.35".
Thread a 13" piece of braided nylon string through the hole in the shaft and tie knots in both ends. The knot must be large enough that it will not pull through the hole.
Wind the string. Hold the top by the ring using your thumb and index finger. Wind the string, hold the knot while you pull it and let it rewind, like a top. Once you have the feel of it pull the string faster and gently put the top down, don't drop it.

comments.text:
Your video makes it look easy - perhaps it is easy for you! My hand eye co-ordination is barely up to the task. I did get it to perform - most impressively, but my 'strike' rate is very poor. More practice is needed.
BTW I broke the cap on assembly and instead of simply making another I designed another one which may be of interest to you. I'll happily email to you if you like.
Mike.

title: Open Academic Robot Kit: 1DOF and 2DOF Joysticks and 5DOF Arm Controller

description.text: This design is still incomplete, with designs and code still to be uploaded and instructions still to be written. Check back soon or email [email protected] to be informed about when this is ready!

1 and 2 degree of freedom joysticks (2DOF with safety switch) for controlling the 6WD robot base plus 5 degree of freedom "master" controller for controlling the 5DOF robot arm in a Master-Slave configuration (the "slave" arm on the robot assumes the same posture as the "master" arm that the operator manually positions). Note: 3D printable designs are licensed CC(BY-SA). Code is licensed GPL V2. This design is part of the Open Academic Robot Kit, a family of robot designs designed to lower the barrier of entry to interesting robotics. All of the designs consist of parts that can either be 3D printed using a low cost FDM printer, or obtained off-the-shelf (or via mail order from various sources) around the world. All designs are released under CC(BY-SA). Software necessary to demonstrate the robot's basic capabilities is also open source.

Plastic holders for a glass bed for Solidoodle 2 that do not protrude above the bed. Note: I'm not using this holders anymore because after a while the inserts tended to bend and not hold the glass properly anymore. I suggest trying this other magnetic mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:54297

These holders are intended to replace paper clips or other things that are normally used to attach a glass piece on top of the heated bed of the solidoodle 2. They have the advantago of staying below the bed, so they allow the usage of the full printing area, and avoid the risk of the extruder crashing.
You will need pieces of glass that are a bit bigger than the bed itself, I suggest 17x15cm.
Print 4 times the "socket" and 4 times the "insert". Once printed, use a small file to elarge the hole of the socket just enough for the insert to slide in.
Carefully place the glass on the bed and draw lines where the edges of the bed are.
Glue the 4 sockets at the four corners. Be careful to use a glue that is strong and resistant to at least 100Â°C. I used UHU Plus 5 minutes.
Once the glue is dry, try placing the glass on the bed and place the inserts. They should fit just below the bed and apply some force that keeps the glass in place. If they don't fit, file a bit the socket to allow for a bit of backlash.

comments.text: I saw your comment about the new magnetic bed holder. While that definitely is better, for anyone (like myself) who hasn't upgraded from this to the magnetic one yet, here's a trick I've learned. If you are having problems with the glass bed sliding around while printing, coat the aluminum plate with kapton (if you still have the old, worn out original kapton that shipped with your machine, that works fine), and spray a ~small~ amount of hairspray to the bottom of the glass. The hairspray sticks to the kapton and keeps the bed from moving around.

Mount Jefferson constructed using both 3 and 1 arc second resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (0.5 million facets for 3 arc second MountJefferson.stl and about 1.4 million facets for the 1 arc second MountJefferson_1arc.stl). The 1 arc second map was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA on my Makerbot 2 and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I get much better results using the heated bed of my Lulzbot Taz 5.

I needed a smaller version of the full Programable Cryptex without loosing the definition of the letters, so I have split the letter ring into 2 (A-M and N-Z). (I was also running out of ABS) This allows any word to be selected by fitting the appropriate ring.

This is a simple grip for the back end of an SD card.  
I designed it for my MakerFarm i3v with the LCD add-on. I print primarily from the SD card, but the card is a bit difficult to remove. For one, it barely sticks out of the slot at all, making you have to grab it with just your fingernails. Second, the spool holder that I use limits the room for my hand to reach in there to grab it. My solution is this grip with a loop attached. Now I can pull out the card easily with one finger.  
I've added two versions, one with side walls and one without. On my i3v, there isn't any room for sidewalls as the card rests just about even with the top panel of the printer, but if you're using this with something else then the sides could make for a better grip on the card.  
The OpenSCAD sources are included, in case you need to tweak anything. I have the SD card insertion pretty low because I don't have much card to grip on my machine (any more and my card wouldn't get inserted into the machine's slot all the way), but it's easily adjustable.

I'd suggest printing with support unless your printer is just stellar with bridging. If you're having a hard time getting just the right thickness for the SD card width (doesn't grip the card well), you could put some ABS slurry in there and let it dry with the card in, or use something like superglue. The presets in the file work well for me so I didn't have to do anything like that.

title: Fibonacci Sphere: A Smoother Sphere for OpenSCAD

description.text: A fibonacci sphere is an approximation for a sphere that is formed from an arbitrary number of roughly equidistant vertices. Pass it any positive number and you'll get a mesh back containing that exact number of vertices for each hemisphere. All vertices in the sphere will be roughly equidistant.

• You get a sphere model that looks better while using fewer vertices.
  • You have precise control over the number of vertices used.
  • In theory, this also allows minkowski() to deliver smoother renders in the same amount of time.

Vertices start out at the meridian and are spaced at regular intervals along the z axis. With that, each vertex is rotated away from its predecessor by a certain angle. That angle is 360 degrees divided by the golden ratio.
For those who want a gentle (and fascinating) introduction as to why this algorithm works, try here

title: 100mm Air raid Siren VERY  VERY  LOUD

description.text:
This is an air raid siren built to go inside a Stuka dive bomber model. The Stuka was a German terror weapon used in WWII. As it dived to drop a bomb, a siren would sound out from the plane to terrify the people they were bombing. This siren is powered by a small 25 amp brushless motor at 850kv on a 3s lipo battery and a 30amp ESC. It is very loud and effective so ramp it up slowly if you make one and worn the neighbours if you live in a place that has tornado's. Have Fun
Go to instructions for links to the motor parts.
I will post a test vid on here soon.

I have made the motor mount in a way that you can import it into Google Sketchup and redesign it to suite what ever motor you are going to use. The outer circular part of the motor mount just glues into the main stator. You will see how it all fits together. This was a cool project and now all my neighbours hate me.

comments.text:
Hi! Can you explain a little bit the connection... I already have everything needed, except for the servo tester. I went to order it, but it says operating voltage is 4.8v to 6v. A 3S lipo is 11.1V. So I'm a little confused... The servo tester, that is to control the speed right? So the connection would be:
Battery -> Servo tester -> ESC -> brushless motor. Is that correct? If not please correct me! Also, this means the servo tester won't last very long i think... but I'm really bad in electronics so please, advise!
Thank you!
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text:
Hi Darth
Ok, The servo tester only controls the input signal to the ESC. It would do the same thing as the receiver in an RC system.The Lipo battery at 11.1v connects directly to the main battery connection on the ESC. The esc will provide the 4.8 volts to power the servo tester vis the signal cable. This is called a BEC (Battery Eliminating Circuit).
Lipo Battery>ESC>Motor
Signal lead from ESC> Servo tester. (some servo testers require a separate 4.8-6v battery to power them.
Let me know if you need any more info and thanks for making the siren.
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text:
Hi Chumsize
Stay tuned and I will post a list of the motor parts and where you can get them very cheap with links.
The Impeller is the part that looks like a fan.
The Stator is the part that looks like a round castle with a hole in the middle.
The motor mount is the round part with four legs on it. The round part of the motor mount fits inside the hole in the stator (castle part). I used ZAP super glue to glue the parts.
The spacer part goes between the motor shaft and the impeller but it has been designed for the motor that has been used to provide a 1mm air gap between the impeller and the stator so the impeller does not bind against the stator when it rotates.
I will add some more pictures with the Impeller removed.

title: Robo3D: Leadnut adapter with z-axis limit switch

description.text:
RoBo3D Autolevel via Mike Kelly is very very nice. This adapter is for modified Robo3D with lead nut and screw, able to buy from Maker's Tool Works.
Uploaded file is for right side. Please mirror by your slicer for left side.

comments.text: Really nice design. I ordered the lead screws and couplers and can't wait to install them this weekend. Did you put any lubrication on the screws or just leave the Delrin alone?
comments.author: Director

comments.text:
In my case, delrin was little tight and I used silicone oil for bicycle chain.
And I have to say, my Robo3D could not move Z to home smoothly with this mod at first time. It was because of friction by not only delrin, but also two Z-rods were not parallel by the assembly quality.
You also might be good to measure distance between the Z-rod at the top in each of when z is top and bottom. Mine has 2mm difference and I've solved it by cutting smooth rod hole on X-idler little deeper.
comments.author: Director

comments.text: I have the rods and adapters, but haven't yet installed them (I'm waiting for me to finish doing the Linear Y-Axis mod when I have to tear the printer apart anyway.)
comments.author: Director

comments.text: I've read that delrin nuts may need to be worked in. I'm going to edit some gcode to repeat a Z up and down many times.
comments.author: Drathus

comments.text: Oh, I've got the y axis mod parts... Just a matter of finding the time and energy to do it. I'm also replacing the steppers with Kysans when I do it, just because. =)
comments.author: Director

comments.text: Just got mine as well. The nuts were pretty tight at first. I gently clamped the ACME rods in a hand drill and ran the nuts back and forth a bunch of times. They are now really smooth. I suggest doing this before assembly. I also marked on one of the rods and nuts with a sharpie to make sure they stayed paired in case there is a difference in the rods. BTW - I'm using my son's thingiverse account here. On the Robo3D forum my user name is SteveC. I'll post here and there how well it works out. Still annoyed that I did not get my Y mod in yet!

title: Stepping Motor Bearing Dust Proof Cover for NEMA17

description.text:
http://bunkai.sakura.ne.jp/bunkai-wp/3d_printer/607/ NEMA17???????????????????
reprap???????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????
PRN3D?????????????????????????
It is a dust proof cover parts of NEMA17 motors.
It is the motor of the size that is used as a standard on reprap, but the motor that is not sealed to the bearing portion of the shaft back there. To protect such a motor, was produced a dust prevention cover.
You have created the PRN3D for, but it is the part that can be used for general purposes.

title: Tamper for La Pavoni grinder sized for 49mm portafilter

description.text: My commercial La Pavoni coffee grinder had a tamper that was too large for my home espresso machine... I finally got around to building a replacement... works great! This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/ka3uQcTW77i
The thread on the push bar is M8 1.25 so I sized the hole at 7mm and self tap it by slowing pushing the bar in.  Seems to work well.  We'll see how it holds up.

description.text:
This is just another Arduino Uno Bumper.  
I prefer to use a rectangular shape, and no need for any screws.
decorative item works well with tea light candle

I have printed this as one item, with a lot of support material, but is simpler as two items, I printed in red PLA and assembled with a small
dowel and super glue.
WIP Soap Box Racer that should be build in the Winter - The Race is in May!

ItÂ´s not really a 3d printable part - bit good for 3 axis CNC in combination with the Printer! Still working on the Steering - the aim is to have a one Stick Steering/Braking with a Helicopter like Joystick ... Still some work to do!
